title.narrative: Phase III Multi-Sector Response for IDPs and Vulnerable Host Communities in Yirol East, Lakes State

description.narrative: Humanitarian needs are pervasive across South Sudan as a result of multiple threats, including armed conflict, inter-communal violence, economic decline, disease and climatic changes. Despite the signing of a peace agreement between warring sides in August 2015, the impact of violence on civilians has been catastrophic. Large sections of the population are displaced and often multiple times due to repeated attacks by different armed forces. As of Feb 2017, 2.2million people are internally displaced, and approximately 1.5 million have fled violence as refugees into neighbouring countries. Over 600,000 children are reported acutely malnourished. Protection for civilians is of particular concern: acts of physical and sexual violence against women, and recruitment of children into armed groups are widespread. CTP proposes to work with Caritas Diocese of Rumbek. CTP has partnered with CDoR for Phase I and II of the Yirol emergency response and has implemented a close-accompaniment model, as CTP technical staff work side by side with CDoR programme staff in the implementation of key FSL and WASH activities. This approach has ensured standards in quality and accountability are reached and maintained, and the technical capacity of partner staff is gradually built through on-job training. Organisational weaknesses in financial management identified by CTP demand a similar approach. CTP has retained management of large-scale procurement until the capacity of CDoR is sufficient to enable them undertake procurement independently. CTP is implementing an organisational development plan over 18 months to enable engender this further. It is planned that Trócaire’s protection advisors will work closely ensuring appropriate protection mechanisms are implemented and global protection cluster standards, and those of the protection cluster in South Sudan, are followed. Capacity building on protection standards and conflict sensitive approaches for CDoR will also underpin this.
